learning_outcomes.description: Critically assess gaps in macroeconomic literature.
Design research questions and research projects to fill the gaps.
Apply empirical and/or quantitative tools to advance research projects.
Effective communication of research findings in academic presentation.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
Students are expected to apply the tools covered in the lectures.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission via Blackboard by the due date and time. In addition, students should email their codes for the computational part to the lecturer.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Presentation 1 due on 1/09/2025 11:00 am.

Presentation 2 due on 15/09/2025 11:00 am

Presentation 3 due on 22/09/2025 11:00 am
assessments.task_description:
Students will perform three presentations during the semester. The first presentation (due on 1/09/2025 11:00 am) consists of presenting the results and analysis of the empirical assignment. The second is a paper discussion (15/09/2025 11:00 am). The third is a dry run for the final presentation of the course (22/09/2025 11:00 am)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students must submit the abstract, the introduction, and the conclusion sections of their thesis. Students are expected to apply the writing techniques discussed in lectures.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission via Blackboard by the due date and time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students present their thesis research at the UQ city campus in front of an audience including invited guests from industry, academia, and/or the public sector. Each presentation should be approximately 10 minutes in duration and demonstrate both comprehensive understanding of the student's research and effective application of presentation techniques covered in the presentation skills workshop. Presentations should be accessible to a general academic audience without specialist knowledge of the topic.

 The presentation should include and demonstrate:

  • Clear articulation of the research question, methodology, and key findings using language accessible to non-specialists
  • Demonstration of critical understanding of the research context and significance
  • Application of presentation techniques taught in the workshop sessions

 

Evaluation

Students will be evaluated on factual accuracy, clarity of communication, organisation and structure, time management, effective use of visual aids, ability to effectively communicate their research to the audience, and more generally the demonstration of presentation skills learned throughout the semester.

Academic Integrity & AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Empirical Macroeconomic Methods I

Basics on Macroeconometric models. Autorregresive models, factor models, and local projection models.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Empirical Macroeconomic Methods I Basics on Macroeconometric models. Autorregresive models, factor models, and local projection models.

learning_activities.topic:
Empirical Macroeconomic Methods II

Identification of macroeconometric models. SVAR and local projections.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Empirical Macroeconomic Methods II Identification of macroeconometric models. SVAR and local projections.
